steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4e7ff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"boeq1","text":"After opening a new Amira project, select File \u003e Open Data, or click+drag the raw data tiff to the empty space under the Project tab. Confirm coordinates and voxel size in the Image Read Parameters window. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":42,"length":16},{"style":"bold","offset":121,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":176,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5jbl3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9gsr2","text":"For higher label resolution: Select the arrow of the raw data object in the Project tab. In the window search bar, type ‘resample’. Select the Resample object. With the Resample object selected, adjust Voxel Size: under Properties to half of the original resolution value. Select Apply, and select the newly generated raw data object as the new working raw data object.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":76,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":143,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":169,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":202,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":220,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":280,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tngv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fd3pk","text":"Select the Segmentation tab to automatically generate a label field. Confirm Image: dropdown under Segmentation Editor is the raw data. Under Materials, ensure the Exterior (Not Assigned) material remains unlocked. The existing Inside material may be renamed and used as the first cell segmentation material. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":11,"length":12},{"style":"bold","offset":77,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":99,"length":19},{"style":"bold","offset":142,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":164,"length":24},{"style":"bold","offset":228,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"56egl","text":"All substructure and organ classes fall under a class type. Amira label fields may be organized by class type to track classes with similar patterns in the data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bib4n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fmun","text":"Muscle ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8p2h0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j1ud","text":"Trunk Muscles","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":13},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bl5kb","text":"The fish contains two main truck muscles, the epaxial and hypaxial muscles separated by the transvese septum. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qeev","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5aemv","text":"Pectoral Girdle Muscles","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":23},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6slt2","text":"Three muscles take their origin at the ventral tip of the posterior cleithrum, the first bony structure to emerge. This is just lateral to the caudal edge of the heart.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"605t4","text":"Abdominal muscle","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"arqm","text":"The abdominal muscle (in the literature called posterior hypaxial muscle) sends long muscle fibers caudo-dorsally to join the ventral boundary of the hypaxial muscle where there is a fascial thickening. It attaches to the ventral side of the epaxial myotomes at the level of myotomes 4, 5, 6.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cs921","text":"Sternohyoid muscle","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11l75","text":"The sternohyoid muscle courses anteriorly and is formed of two consecutive myotomes reaching the urohyal cartilage.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqo0k","text":"Sternobranchial muscle","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98kf2","text":"Sternobranchial muscle (my name). The third muscle of the group courses dorsally and attaches to the base of the skull at the level of the base of 5th ceratobranchial arch. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"645be","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cm5b","text":"Branchial Muscles","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":17},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbcrj","text":"Branchial Levator 5.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brsn7","text":"This muscle attaches at the caudal rim of the ear bone and project ventro-medially to attach to the fifth branchial arch. This is one of the muscles which keep together the cranium and the jaw. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3c9t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gfkg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2fvip","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"99j1t","text":"Cartilage","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dh6jp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6n718","text":"Neurocranium","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":12},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"85cg3","text":"The cranium is formed of different cartilaginous structures. The base of the brain can be divided into the prechordal elements and the para and postchordal elements. The ethmoid plate connects to the basal plate (also parachordal cartilage) via trabeculae. This basal plate abuts the notochord. The basicapsule emanates from the basal plate encircling the base of the developing ear. It comprises the anterior, lateral and posterior basicapsular commissure. This is also sometimes referred to as the auditory capsule. At the anterior portion of the basal plate a perforated fossa is present formed by lateral commissure through which vessels run. The basal plate extends caudal to merge with the occipital plate which extends two dorsal elements, the occipital arches. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ho6o","text":"The cleithrum, a prominent vertical structure, acts as a central element of the zebrafish skeletal system. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e63g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2cp8s","text":"Notochord. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d75jj","text":"A structural and signaling element located directly under the spinal cord containing large vacuolated cells surrounded by notochord sheath cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ol4g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8fpf5","text":"The pharyngeal teeth pad is situated at the upper region of the pharynx.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2k0rs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fne3f","text":"Gills are protected by the operculum, a covering that shields the delicate structures underneath. The gills themselves are individually labeled.","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33hgp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bq6j0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35hc9","text":"The pectoral fins are anterior limbs situated on each side of the fish.","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3tv1h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6bbve","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"53b8j","text":"Sensory organs include the eyes, with distinct labels for structures such as the iris and exterior, and the ears, which encompass the entire organ along with its internal compartments. Hair cells line the base of the ear in uniform lines.","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":27,"length":4},{"style":"bold","offset":108,"length":4},{"style":"bold","offset":185,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5u2np","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8dci5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgsad","text":"Organs include:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2l5fm","text":"Gastrointestinal tract: starts at the mouth, extending along the body cavity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ono6","text":"Heart: includes the ventricle, a large, heavily lined cavity, the atrium, the more dorsal/caudal, thin cavity, and ductus arteriosus, the muscular outlet. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":20,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":65,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":114,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adnfl","text":"Kidney:
